params.note: Protocol involves complicated cell isolation, seeding and bioprinting processes with challenges in recapitulating proximal tubule physical characteristics such as lumen diameter and interaction with supportive cell types.

hPSCs can be directly differentiated into multicellular tissues resembling in vivo counterparts; hPSC-derived kidney organoids develop segmented nephrons with proximal, distal, stromal and endothelial elements.
Standard kidney organoids model developing kidney but show PT immaturity at phenotypic and functional levels.
This protocol describes a methodology to generate intact proximalized nephrons in organoid format with cortical stroma, loop of Henle, and endothelial populations.

PT-enhanced organoids display superior PT maturation compared to standard organoids, with evidence of S1/S2/S3 PT cell types, improved functionality, and suitability for PT damage and disease modeling.

Applications include screening for nephrotoxic side effects, pharmaceutical efficacy testing, discovery of novel treatments for proximal tubular diseases, modeling inherited/acquired diseases with PT dysfunction, kidney developmental studies, and bioengineering approaches.

Limitations include overall immaturity, inability to culture long-term for full maturation, low expression of transporters SLC22A2/OCT2 and SLC22A6/OAT1, and recurrent off-target differentiation into neural, muscle, and cartilage lineages.
PT-enhanced organoids arise from a self-established centralized core of WNT antagonism with pre-cartilage population and cortical stroma; off-target populations may hinder clinical translation.
PT-enhanced organoids show limited GATA3 expression, suggesting poor patterning to distal connecting segments.

Current inability to simultaneously generate all kidney cell populations in a single differentiation step limits nephron development and critical interactions (e.g., ureteric bud, nephron progenitors, stroma).
hPSC passaging and expansion for differentiation is performed feeder-free in TesR-Essential 8 (E8) medium with Matrigel support.
Passaging is performed at 80% confluency, 2 days before differentiation induction (day -2), at a 1:3 split ratio to ensure cells are in exponential growth phase before seeding.
